• This law is called the 'Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023'.
• The complete title establishes the legal identity of this code.
• It consists of four Hindi words followed by the year 2023.
Subsection-1 states: This law is officially called 'Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023'. Example: Just like saying 'My name is John' - this subsection declares the law's official name.

Subsection-1 exists to officially declare the law's name for legal recognition. Without this subsection, the law would have no formal identity. Example: Like a birth certificate that officially names a child, this subsection officially names the law.

Subsection-1 appears at the very beginning of the BNSS 2023 document. It is the first subsection of Section 1. Example: Found on the opening page of the official BNSS text, before any other provisions.

Subsection-1 came into effect in 2023 when the law was enacted. This naming provision became official with the passage of the Act. Example: Since 2023, this subsection has been the legal reference point for the law's name.
Subsection-1 is the naming clause of BNSS 2023. It is the first and foundational subsection of Section 1. Example: Among all subsections, this is the one that specifically addresses the law's title.

Subsection-1 works by providing a simple declarative statement: 'This law is called...'
It establishes legal nomenclature through direct declaration. Example: Legal professionals cite this subsection when referencing the law's official name in documents.

subsection_2.title: Special Provisions for Nagaland and Tribal Areas

content.text:
Subsection-2: Special Provisions for Nagaland and Tribal Areas

• This subsection exempts Nagaland and tribal areas from most provisions of BNSS.
• Only Chapters IX, XI, and XII apply to these areas by default.
• State Governments can choose to apply other provisions with modifications.

Subsection-2 states that most provisions of BNSS do not apply to Nagaland and tribal areas, except Chapters IX, XI, and XII. State Governments can notify to apply other provisions with modifications. Example: Like giving special autonomy to certain regions based on their unique needs.

Subsection-2 exists to respect the special constitutional status of Nagaland and tribal areas. These regions have unique cultural, social, and legal traditions that need protection. Example: Like Article 371A which grants special provisions to Nagaland, this subsection ensures their autonomy while maintaining national legal framework.

Subsection-2 applies to: (a) The State of Nagaland, and (b) Tribal areas as defined under the Constitution. These are specially protected regions with distinct legal status. Example: Scheduled Areas under Fifth Schedule and Tribal Areas under Sixth Schedule of the Indian Constitution.

Subsection-2 came into effect with BNSS in 2023. State Governments can issue notifications at any time to apply provisions to these areas. There's no fixed timeline - it depends on when the State Government decides. Example: A State can notify today, tomorrow, or years later based on their assessment.

Subsection-2 identifies: (1) Which areas are exempt: Nagaland and tribal areas. (2) Which chapters DO apply: Chapters IX, XI, and XII. (3) Which provisions DON'T apply: All other chapters. Example: If BNSS has 20 chapters, only 3 automatically apply to these regions; remaining 17 are optional.

Subsection-2 works through a notification system:
Step 1: State Government decides which provisions to apply
Step 2: Issues official notification
Step 3: Can add supplemental or consequential modifications
Step 4: Provisions become applicable as per notification. Example: Like a menu where the State picks what legal provisions suit their region best.

content.text:
Explanation to Subsection-2: Definition of Tribal Areas

• Defines what 'tribal areas' means for the purpose of Subsection-2.
• Refers to territories included in Assam's tribal areas as of January 21, 1972.
• Excludes the municipality of Shillong from this definition.
• Based on Paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution.

The Explanation states: 'Tribal areas' means the territories which were part of Assam's tribal areas immediately before January 21, 1972, as mentioned in Paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution, except areas within Shillong municipality. Example: Like defining a specific geographic region using a historical reference date.

This Explanation exists to provide legal clarity on which areas qualify as 'tribal areas' under Subsection-2. It prevents confusion by fixing a specific date (January 21, 1972) and constitutional reference. Example: Like defining 'minor' as 'person below 18 years' - it removes ambiguity about who qualifies for special provisions.

The Explanation applies to territories that were: (a) Part of Assam's tribal areas before January 21, 1972, (b) Mentioned in Paragraph 20 of Sixth Schedule, and (c) NOT within Shillong municipality limits. Example: Areas like parts of Meghalaya that were tribal areas of Assam before 1972, excluding Shillong city.

The Explanation uses January 21, 1972 as the cut-off date. This is historically significant because it was when Meghalaya became a full state. Territories included as tribal areas 'immediately before' this date qualify. Example: If an area was tribal area on January 20, 1972, it qualifies; if designated after January 21, 1972, it doesn't.

The Explanation identifies: (1) Which areas qualify: Former Assam tribal areas as of Jan 21, 1972. (2) Which constitutional provision: Paragraph 20 of Sixth Schedule. (3) Which areas are excluded: Shillong municipality. Example: Of all tribal areas, only those meeting these three criteria qualify for Subsection-2 exemption.

The Explanation works by establishing three criteria:
Step 1: Check if area was tribal area of Assam
Step 2: Verify status immediately before Jan 21, 1972
Step 3: Confirm it's referenced in Sixth Schedule Para 20
Step 4: Ensure it's NOT within Shillong municipality
All four must be satisfied. Example: Like a checklist - only areas meeting all conditions qualify as 'tribal areas' under BNSS.
